results.title: Under my skin
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Jacqueline Matisse
results.brief_description: A succinct Australian claymation which explores the demise of a doomed relationship between a beautiful French poodle, Fifi, and a somewhat dejected looking flea, who has been given his marching orders in a most diplomatic fashion. (Awards: St Kilda Film Festival, 2001; the Vancouver Effects and Animation Festival, 1999 and various other international festivals)

results.title: Unconscious motivation
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how unconscious motives can influence and direct everyday thoughts. A demonstration of hypnosis of two subjects during which an experimental neurotic conflict is produced, is allowed to manifest itself in the posthypnotic conscious state, and is then relieved by aiding the subjects to recall the implanted traumatic material. Of interest to psychiatrists, psychoanalysts, psychiatric nurses, medical students and students of psychology.

results.title: Unconditional surrender
results.brief_description: Shows the production of polio vaccine in a large pharmaceutical laboratory and describes the licensing procedures at the National Institute of Health. Features President Eisenhower and his grandchild, RAndy Kerr, the first child to receive the vaccine in 1954. Also features Dr Jonas Salk.

results.title: Uncle Smiley goes to the beach
results.creator_credit: Joe Sutherin, GME Films, Learning Corporation of America and Jim Burroughs
results.brief_description: Shows Uncle Smiley and his group playing where land and sea meet. Emphasises the possibilities for either use or misuse of public beaches. Uncle Smiley gets careless and needs to be rescued by a lifeguard and the children help to clean up a nearby polluted beach. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Uncle Smiley goes recycling
results.creator_credit: Joe Sutherin, Learning Corporation of America and Jim Burroughs
results.brief_description: Introduces the term “recycling” to children and provides information about different recycling possibilities. Uncle Smiley and the children take their waste collection to a recycling depot where it is sorted prior to re-use. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Uncle Smiley goes planting
results.creator_credit: Joe Sutherin, GME Films and Jim Burroughs
results.brief_description: Shows Uncle Smiley and children planting trees in an area ravaged by forest fire, utilising modern reforestation techniques. Also shows other aspects of conservation relating to the usage of the forest. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Uncle Smiley goes camping
results.creator_credit: Joe Sutherin, GME Films, Learning Corporation of America and Jim Burroughs
results.brief_description: Shows children how to protect their environment by keeping it clean and safe. Uncle Smiley takes the children on a camping trip where they see that there are rules campers should follow to ensure the safety of themselves and others. Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Uncle Smiley and the junkyard playground
results.creator_credit: Joe Sutherin, GME Films and Jim Burroughs
results.brief_description: Uncle Smiley shows his young friends how a playground can be created from discarded junk. Using hammers, saws, shovels, spanners, wooden boards soon become slides, cable reels become cars and tyres and ropes become swings. Paint, a tree and flowers also help to brighten the junkyard. The children discover that the best play equipment need not be expensive. Suitable for lower and middle primary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Joe Sutherin, GME Films and Jim Burroughs

results.title: Uncle Saddam
results.creator_credit: RDF International, Rajonvision and Joel Soler
results.brief_description: Made prior to the 2003 invasion of Iraq by the United States and their western allies, this biographical documentary offers an insight into the life and background of Iraqi ruler, the infamous and brutal Saddam Hussein. Director Joel Soler, on the pretence of filming Iraq’s suffering under UN sanctions, managed to produce this somewhat satirical and surrealistic portrayal of a meglomaniac who “claims he is a direct descendant of Mohammed”, taking us into the sanctity of Saddam’s palaces and introducing us to the various members of his family. Discusses Saddam’s obsession with architecture and monuments (all dedicated to the man himself), his brutal politics and warmongering and his egocentricities in a rather irreverent manner. Narration written by Scott Thompson, a former member of the comedy troupe “The Kids in the Hall” and read by comic actor Wallace Langham. Includes b&w archival footage and stills. Winner of several awards including New Orleans and Northampton Film Festivals. NB: Contains some scenes which may disturb.
